channel.title: Distributions on Datumorphism
channel.description: Recent content in Distributions on Datumorphism

item.title: Normal Distribution
item.description: Visualization Math The formula of normal distribution is $$ \begin{equation} e^{ ( (x - \mu) / \sqrt{2} \sigma )^2 } \end{equation} $$ where $\mu$ controls the “center” or “peak” of the distribution and $\sigma$ tells us how “wide” or “disperse” the distribution is. To understand the distribution, we take some limits. $x = \mu$ First of all, when $x = \mu$ we have $$ e^0 = 1. $$ Notice the argument of the exponential is some squared value and can not be negative.
